32720867.review:
The most honest review I can give is this (tl;dr will be below:

I'm a weeb. And I like hack and slash games. Games like Akibastrip or Senran Kagura usually end up being my favorite types of games to spend a summer on. So I did enjoy this. 

But that being said, the characters aren't really too in-depth even on character models. There's not much to "collect" either. Kill hordes of enemies, they drop coins, and those coins offer upgrades, but that's really about it. As far as I can tell, there's not even a shop, and according to the progression screen, I played this game for 2 hours and I'm 15% done. 

Also they talk. Forever. I don't even know what the plot's about at this point because it grew so boring and cumbersome that I started skipping dialogues. Remember: games like Senran and Akibastrip are my favorite. I don't skip dialogues often. But this one, once they start its like they never want to stop. If I had even speedred all the dialogue instead of skipping I'd probably be another hour or two longer in this game just from that.

Long story short, this is a simple time killer. Which is exactly what I wanted and also exactly what I expected. So I enjoyed it. But it's a surface game. There's not a lot of depth or progression as far as anything is concerned. I waited till the Steam summer sale to buy it for like $5 so it was definitely worth the money I spent on it, but I wouldn't recommend paying over 15 for it, let alone the full $30 price tag.



Tl;dr?
Pros: Weeby, hyperdimension neptunia characters, simple, hack and slash. Simple, casual fun with silly strip mechanics of AKibastrip or Senran Kagura games. You don't have to have played previous Hyperdimension games to keep up, but if you do it helps. Funny dialogue and humor, often breaks the 4th wall at times, lots of cultural references to other games and anime.

Cons: Lack of any depth given to characters, combat or plot, LOTS of talking that you're eventually going to just start skipping because it goes on forever. 

Recommendation: Buy on sale if you like very simple hack and slash weeb games like Akibastrip or Senran Kagura, but I don't recommend any one buy it at full price. And I was REALLY hoping I wouldn't feel that way because these types of games are my favorite kinds but I honestly couldn't see myself feeling justified spending over $15 on this (and I have Senran Kagura Peach Beach Splash preordered for my ps4 currently).

31352345.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U is definitly one of those games where prefrence is a big deal. For me, it just wasn't for me.

First thing I noticed when I first picked it up was the ENG audio. Luckily there is a JAP audio selection in the options menu as well as subtitles. The downside with this is that not everything is subbed. There were several sections in the game where you just had characters speak without subtitles. To me that's a bit annoying, but not a major complaint since their voices are all pretty great.

The battle system feels very repetitive and quite boring actually. You can pretty much grab a character, find one combo that doesn't have a huge idle time afterwards and just repeat. Of course this doesn't work for every stage, but I found this doable through most of it. The character interactions between the characters are great until about hour 8 where you're getting repeats every 20secs or so since it will take almost no time at all to get decent at this game. The real challenges don't come in until after the main story. That's when things get more intense, but even then there is just so little there. 

The story itself isn't very memorable, but it is actually one of the things I like most about the game. It's cute, it's actually written very well, and the small talk between the major events at time are great. There are several refrences to games that came out around U's first release date and boy are they great little refrences. I honestly think this game would have done better as novel compared to a Hack n Slash genre based game.

I could go on to pick small things here and there, but here is my overall opinion.

It's a great game for Neptunia fans, but not a great game for Hack n Slash fanatics. I would not recommend this unless they were a Neptune fan. 

I got this game when it was on sale for about $5 and I would say I would max at $10 for this. So unless you [u]really[/u] want it, don't pay it's current price. If I paid that much for this I would be a bit upset.

31271265.review:
It looks great, it sounds great, its got entertaining brawling, loads of missions, and tons of rewards to earn for bashing more monsters. Stuff ranging from stat buffs that apply across all characters to new weapons and costumes. The combat is a (dumb) blast - its really just mashing out simple combos and dashing around groups of enemies, occasionally broken up by unleashing special moves and swapping characters, until you can transform and then really wreak some havoc on large groups of enemies and bosses - but it is very enjoyable. Sometimes you need more 'Fighting Force' than 'Bayonetta', you know? 

The girls' playstyles are diverse enough and have just enough to learn that you'll have fun experimenting and getting better with each style the more you play. Plus there's enough enemy variety, and there are enough ways to power up, as the game goes on to keep it from getting too repetitive throughout the entire playtime, I think (though the level designs are very simplistic). Its just really well done - the animations are great, knockbacks and hitstuns feel perfect, and there's loads of great Visual FX to provide rewarding feedback to everything you do. All the while, you're fighting to tunes that sound straight out of a Playstation-era Mega Man X title (there's a lot of great stuff here; catchy melodies, good arrangements, high energy stuff. Classic Japanese video game music with a "cyber" veneer).
 
If you're worried about it getting pervy - especially since this game, that heavily advertises its "costume breaking", features lots of characters who are, after all, little girls - fear not! You can adjust... well, everything that may grate. You want to give them unbreakable outfits? Go for it. Wanna mute the voices**? On a character-by-character basis, even. Conversation/dialogue scenes lasting too long? Skip'em. There's a solid amount of "quality-of-life" refinements here, which is great. This is definitely a good "podcast game" - just something to mindlessly play while doing something else, so adjusting your experience a bit is welcome. Just make sure to head into the Options and the SETUP menu (on the World Map screen) to dig into all this stuff as soon as possible. Otherwise you'll miss out on some stuff that would really up your enjoyment of the title early on, including leveling up your characters via the Medal system.

( ** - to be clear, the voice acting is great. The script is generally pretty cute and funny, while the English cast are matched well to their characters and crushes every line. The problem is just that the voices get so repetitive in stages that you're going to want to mute them before the first one is over. Literally, they have to announce every special move they do, as well as throw out the same 3 or 4 quips every few seconds. The dialogue scenes are good, but the in-game just gets too obnoxious.  )

Basically, if you're looking for a fun, flashy time beating the crap out of loads of enemies - one that's still satisfying-to-play and simple-to-grasp (but not AS simplistic as something like arena brawlers Croixleur Sigma or Mitsurugi Kamui Hikae) - this absolutely gets the job done. Its the modern equivalent of a Streets of Rage-type experience, with vibrant candy colors and magical anime girls: sometimes that's all you need ;)

29294683.review:
It might be more appropriate to give this game a 'neutral' rating (yes, I know it's a Nep-Nep game, but hear me out on this one!)

As far as characters, interactions, ect, everything is what you would expect from a Neptunia game: aka, wonderful.  Lighthearted, humorous, interesting, this part is good.  A lot of the music is from other games (a lot of stages and monsters too), but that didn't really bother me: I was happy with that too.  The length of the game was fine for me (whatever my play time is is a good estimate, maybe a little lower because I left the game on sometimes.  I did everything except one notably frustrating achievement, so if you want to do that too, add quite a few hours.)

The combat in the game?  Oh man, this is TEDIOUS and not really that fun.  It's fun for the first couple of hours, and then... it's just tedious.  Literally, you just do the combat so you can get to the next interaction with the characters so you can laugh and be amused.  Everything else in the game is great or good, this is the only thing that isn't... but it IS a big part of the game.  So just be warned.  

Perhaps pick this game up on a sale if you are a Neptunia fan: if you haven't played this series before, I would recommend a different game to start with, and then come back to this one depending on how you liked the other one.

29108524.review:
If you don't mind a more repetitive type of Musou games locked in small arenas and love NepNeps, this game could be fun to beat since you do get funny additions to the NepNep dialogues (not cannon of course), as long as you're not going after achievements or just wanting to max out everything in the game. Reaching max level doesn't need grinding as long as you tackle the post game content, however, reaching max Lily level does require grinding. My play time as of writing this review is 34h, 2/3rd of that being the Lily grind for each character up to level 9. It sucks out the fun since you can't even pretend that you're doing a "new" quest and are just grinding the same stages over and over.

Other than that, the game runs alright, no bugs no glitches no slowdowns, steady 60fps at 1080p with the upscaled Vita graphics that aren't even rendered in 1080p. But it's NepNep, it ain't NepNep if it doesn't look budget. I could swear that all dungeons and models were ripped straight out of the Rebirth series with minor alteration.

So I guess it's a decent purchase during a sale, but wouldn't recommend it outside of sales because it's really budget and doesn't have a lot of good content. But since it's NepNep I'll hit the thumbs up button right away.

The storymode to end game is quite short, if you want to blast through it but post end game content is massive, and if like me you want to 100% this, you will be here for awhile.

27769027.review:
If you've never played a Hyperdimension Neptunia game, brace yourself. The whole series is a glorious satire of the competition between Microsoft, Sony, Sega, and Nintendo. If you're an otaku and know what Hetalia Axis Powers is, then consider this series the Hetalia of Video Games.

You have the big consoles represented along with their portable counterparts (Microsoft doesn't have a portable counterpart though) and ALL of the characters are portrayed as anime styled girls, some of which obvious jiggle physics (looking at Vert/Green Heart, the XBox representative as the one with the most generous...physics). However, what sets this game apart from the rest, is that it's not a turn based game. Instead it's a hack and slash game similar to Senran Kagura (and even features the costume break mechanic of the latter, only not to such an extreme).

Plot wise, the game takes place during a lull in the fighting of the "Console War" (yeah...dead serious...this is just the beginning), which regularlly rocks the world of Gameindustri (I warned you). Basically it's not some big fate of the universe story. Rather these two journalists named Dengekiko and Famitsu (Blaitant satires of the Dengeki and Famitsu gaming magazines) are trying to write articles on the four consoles and arrange a series of quests to test the main cast and get a good idea of their performance.

The game itself is quite fun and enjoyable. The cutscenes are agonizingly long though but aside from that, the overall game is still fun. The humor is quite well played.

I do recommend you have an XBox controller for this game. It will make gameplay 10x easier than with a mouse and keyboard.

26580404.review:
Neptunia U is a rather simple action game with a big grind if you want to get all the achievements and hear all the interactions between the characters.  While there's some character configuration and playstyle choices you can make, almost all of the game can be completed by spamming attacks.  As the game goes on it gets very repetitive, and there's just not enough story or character interaction to make up for it.

I had no crashing or other technical issues, but there are frequent short loading screens that slow down everything.  (This game cries out to be copied to a RAM disk.)

If you want a hack-and-slasher RPG, you're probably better off looking at other games for deeper storylines and/or more interesting gameplay.  Neptunia fans will want to Nep it up, but you may want to wait for a sale.  If you're looking for an introduction to the Neptunia franchise, I'd recommend Re;Birth1 instead.

24664208.review:
Pros: Its different from the other Neptunia games in the series. In my opinion, I like how it's more of a hack and slash free roaming styled RPG. Graphics have improved a lot since Re;birth 1 and dialogue has also shown some improvements. Clever character health and CPU mechanics, as you can continue to switch characters at any time you want. Lily ranks have improved and you don't have to buy outfits anymore, the game gives you them to have fun customising the different characters.

Cons: However, this game has a massive grinding component to it, and a bit of flaws with its recommended levels during quests. Sometimes, you could be 5+ levels higher than the recommended levels in quests, but enemies will still be able to take you down EASILY (especially if they are able to paralyse you) As you progress through the story, you get new weapons and skills, however, very few of them. 

Overall, this game has improved and shown lots of redeeming qualities, especially against Re;birth 1. So, if you're into hack'n'slashes, fanservice (and lots of it), or RPGs, I recommend this, and give this a thumbs up. :)

24564152.review:
Neptunia U is in the branch of "lukewarm Neptunia spinoffs" and theres been several now. This one basically being a musou map based brawler it has alot of short commings that make it weak even in compared to other musou style games. The biggest complaint is the customization or lack thereof of it. Even Senran Kagura, which is a game based on an anime and anime based games are notorious for lacking in super deep details, offers a vastly large amount of customization options for the player.

Nep U offers about 3 weapons and 1 alternate outfit a character and accessories that do not visually change the characters appearance. This does not help alleviate the repeativeness of the game at all, which it does get very repeatitive with the forgettable story and similar missions in similar environments. Even the fan service aspect of the game is lacking when compared to other games that have done it. The entire game feels lacking and rushed.

I can only recommend this game if you are hardcore neptunia fan and will play anything involving them, if not theres far better of the same genre to spend your money on, the aforementioned Senran Kagura game which is also now on steam would be a good example.

24419417.review:
This is a bit of a hard one to reccomend, just because it is such a niche thing. The game is in the style of the Senran Kagura games, but with the charm and setting of Hyperdimension, but it doesn't play as well as them. The gameplay very quickly (pretty much right after the tutorial) becomes "hit quick attack until you have a 4000 combo and win" on every level. The game also does away with all the rpg aspects of the previous games sans item equiping-though without item crafting- and basic leveling. Story is also very thread bare, being the shortest of the Hyperdimension games on PC and just sort of putting an enemy there and saying "oh no, shes invincible, better keep doing the same type of missions over and over again until we have this power to kill her." Also, in the fashion of this series, you have seen most of the enemies and all of these levels before.

But I still recomend it, because if you have played any of the previous games in the series, you know what you are in for if you watch a gameplay trailer. It has the characters you love from this series. It has the self referential and self aware comedy of the series. It has the same enemies and levels from the series. It is just like all the other games in this series, just with a different way of playing it. I enjoyed my time with the game, and absolutely recomend getting if you are okay with spending $30 on 7-10 hours of gameplay. If not, I highly recommend getting it on sale, as I did.

24398558.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U Action Unleashed is an action game set in the Neptunia universe. If you like the regular RPG games, then you will likely enjoy this one as well. It isn’t as good, for a couple of reasons. Firstly, it has more action, but a lot less plot and I like the stories in the other games better. There’s not even multiple endings to explore. Secondly, the fighting can get a little too repetitive, especially when grinding the final few achievements. 

It is still worth checking out, but I can’t be as enthusiastic as I was with the other games.

24396615.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia is a series of games which does what it intends to do extremely well: Advertise skimpily clad anime girls!

The game is largely about a group of girls and their younger sisters who set out to become....Well pretty much cute cuddly teddy bear murderers for hire? Honestly, as with many Japanese storylines, I can't make heads or tails of it. It seems to be sort of all over the place.

The only thing truly consistent about it, though, is that girls strip and kill a whoooole lotta cute things, for reasons I cannot even begin to comprehend. Trust me, I googled it, and I still don't understand.

So instead of trying to put a logic lable on this game, I'll just put an 18+ on it instead.

Graphics wise, the game is mediocre at best. There's little to no shaders in the game, and the enemies are all large or small cookie cutter editions of themselves. Really not at all impressive.
The art style, however, is a whole lot different. It's wonderfully drawn, and clearly the artist(s) knew what they were doing when making these scenes and characters.
Voice acting for English is, as per usual, awkward and kinda crappy. I don't suggest playing this in English. Then again I didn't even check if there IS a Japanese version....Well if there is, use it. There's no way it's worse than the English dub.

There...really is little to nothing else for me to say about this...I mean what did you expect? This is literally one, maybe one and a half, steps above Sakura Clicker. It's a bunch of girls, with powers inspired by some 60 year old tech-retarded person's ideas of what technology and computers are about, whose clothes are the CHEAPEST knockoff crap I've ever seen, considering just how easily it breaks! If you can actually fill an entire review with useful, concrete information to give about a game whose entire selling point is that it caters to the weeaboos need for skimpy waifu material, then you seriously need to re-evaluate your life.

24386907.review:
El universo HyperDimension Neptunia cambia radicalmente. No, no cambiamos de mundo, seguimos en Gamindustri. Lo que cambia es el sistema de lucha. Los que habeis jugado los otros HDN, recordareis el combate por turnos. Pues eso desaparece, cambiando a un sistema de lucha en tiempo real, por lo que hay que dar golpes en todas direcciones. Y nunca mejor dicho, porque no nos atacara un grupo pequeñito de monstruos, sino una autentica horda que ira saliendo en oleadas.

Tendras un grupo de 10 personajes femeninos que controlar: las 4 CPUs, las 4 candidatas (CPU Candidates), y 2 personajes especiales que, como soy taaaaaaaan mala, no dire quienes son.

El juego gira en torno a las quests que hay que ir completando. Normalmente puedes enviar a cualquiera de los 10 personajes sin restriccion (puedes llevar 2 como maximo), pero hay quests que restringen personajes; sin ir mas lejos, las dos primeras misiones separan a las CPUs de las candidatas. Pero hay otras misiones en las que solo puedes llevar a dos personajes, o unclusive solo uno. Si, todas pueden hacerse con solo un personaje.

El uso de habilidades ha cambiado ligeramente. Usando el mando, puedes abrir el menu de habilidades y elegir una de las 3 habilidades "equipadas". Pero eso si, no todas las habilidades del personaje estan disponibles aqui.

Y ademas, no podia faltar lo que se espera de estos juegos: humor a raudales y comentarios rompiendo la 4ª pared.

24340797.review:
Even as a fan of the other games in the main series, I cannot recommend this game.  It is extremely light on content, heavy on grinding, and the sole focus on the game is getting the main characters into a state of undress.  This is particularly troubling given the younger age of some of the characters.  Besides, if you want to look at half-naked women, the internet exists.  There's plenty of that for free.

The story in this one doesn't hold up, there is some amusing banter between the characters but it's still not to the level of Re;Birth 1 or 3.  The balance in this game is god awful as well.  The only thing that really matters is how constantly the characters can attack, in order to keep the swarms of enemies off you.  In this regard, there is only one real winner.  Neptune, in her Purple Heart form, is BY FAR the most competent fighter, enough so that running anyone else is basically pointless, unless you are forced to.  Add to the the fact that the leveling system seems to be based on how well you perform with big combos, Neptune can reach max level very early in the game, when most characters are barely into their teens.

This game just isn't as entertaining, and I can't recommend it even if it goes on deep sale.  A real disappointment.

24202654.review:
+ is a pro
- is a cons
= is a neutral

Story
= While Hyperdimension Neptunia U : Action Unleashed doesn't act as direct sequel(or you can say it as non-canon),
it only gives you a fun time, whacky, cringe, 4th wall conversation, but its still fun to read.}
It all began when 2 journalist of Gameindustri, Dengekiko and Famitsu wanted to make articles about CPU and CPU candidates and suddenly lot of quests suddenly appeared for them, who's behind this ? Learn more by playing it !
You can finish the main campaign around 9-10 hours, pretty short.

Gameplay
+ Its a pure hack n slash, action game like the title of the game, for me it gives a new feel for the series.
+ Various and unique combos for each character
- Then again, it starts to get boring if you just smash that I button over and over again.
- Stunlock ain't fun at all. You can't do anything until horde of mobs stop atacking yoiu.
Yes, you can nullify that by using Anti Paralyzing Patch but still..
+ Ripped Clothes are the best feature in this game. Works everytime for me.
- Camera control is awful.

Lily Rank
= The tedious feature from the series is back. 

Quest
- Quests are of course, repetitive and sometimes annoying especially the Irregular Quest. 
Yes, its challenging but I see it it annoying as the objectives are kinda..weird.
- They doesn't tell you which quest is a story quest. It gives me headache.

Medal Collection
= Want a new gear ? There is no shop in this game but they present to you a new feature, Medal Collection.
Example, get 100 'A' Monster's medal to get stats/gear.
- Medal Collection UI also gives me headache, I wish they add some kind of icon that can tell you which medal that you can unlock or medal that you have completed. Instead, they ask you to keep checking each medal. What a hindrance.

Dungeon
= Only new few terrain/dungeon and they are still using old layout from previous games.

Music
= Only new few bgms and they are (again) using old classic bgms from previous series.

Conclusion:
A decent spin-off from Neptunia series.
I give it 7/10.

Doesn't have the best story, but it has plenty of good plot...

But in all seriousness, It's a lot of fun, and even though it's story isn't amazing, it's really fun if you like tearing through hordes of enemies. I really love it, the combos are pretty fun to tear through enemies with, though not as varied as something like One Piece Pirate Warriors 3 (I really like that combo system).

23971949.review:
*Sees red Not Recommended box*

***Was this review helpful? Durr, no***

Now that the biased idiots who love upvoting shitty positive one-liner reviews have accomplished their goal, they can go **** themselves.

The story to Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Boredom Unleashed is that Dengekiko and Famitsu plan to write articles based on the Goddesses doing monotonous quests with both the CPU's and Candidates deciding to split into two groups to see who can one-up each other for the best featured article. Yup that's it.

There are 10 characters to choose from; Neptune, Noire, Blanc, Vert, Nepgear, Uni, Rom, Ram, Dengekiko and Famitsu who all surprisingly play differently from one another (besides Rom & Ram). Each character has the usual weak and strong attack expected in every hack n' slash with 3 special skills (out of a choice of 4) to use at their disposal. Later on in the story you'll unlock EXE and Lily specials which break the game even further.

Quests consist of the same garbage like "Defeat x amount of enemies", "Defeat x mid-bosses", "Collect x items". There's at least one irregular quest in every location that will bring something new to the table. Defeating the braindead AI mobs will grant medals which can be used for permanent stat boots and unlocking weapons/accessories for each respective character. 

A "new" feature introduced in the game is clothing destruction which grants a 50% EXE Drive Gauge Boost. Then of course there's the usual HDD transformations with Uni, Rom and Ram's making an easy game even easier since the three characters mentioned only require the mashing of a single button for victory.

Gamindustri Gauntlet is a half-baked Vs mode that's easily forgotten tournament. One completion will unlock the last trump card this snore-fest of a game has to offer while 17 additional completions will grant one access to the most OP accessories.

Last at the top of the **** mountain is Neptral Tower. 50 floors x 5 = 250 floors of grueling pain. Each floor just consists of pounding the same asset recycled enemies from story mode except this time you're stuck with a single team the entire way through. The 50th floor is just the same lackluster final boss battle except this time Compile Heart came up with the genius idea of giving it even more HP, exciting right?

But wait there's MORE. Oh no, if you thought all that was enough to make you delete the game from your Steam library just wait endure the most painful task of them all, LILY GRINDING. While entirely optional, it IS required for 100% achievement completion and arguably the best feature this game has to offer... Lily rank conversations.

There you have it. Senran Neptunia: Action Unleashed is worth no one's time unless you're into clothing destruction, waifus, or panty flashing picnics. The barbones combo system is shallow and the customization is a complete joke compared to MegaTagmension Blanc + Neptune vs Zombies. I would only advise buying this game if it's 70-80% off.

By all means, this game deserves a negative review. It plays like silk, at a smooth 60 fps, but..that doesn't help ist much when it has less complexity than even dynasty warriors. You enter HDD and press X, or as Noire, Y, to release a wide sweeping attack. The enemies are mindless, and the gameplay is tedious, especially when objectives like "Defeat 1500" enemies appear. It's simply mashing buttons while wishing you could do something else at the same time to speed the process along. 

The clothes tearing feature is..pretty much useless, though I'd suggest getting a nude patch like I did for the jiggle physics the game has to offer. 

The dialogue is generally pretty charming, if you can stand to read through all of it. Like any JRPG, it's a mountain of text upon another mountain of text. The voice acting is decent, be it English, or japanese. 

You can run through the entire game in 8, boring, very wasteful hours, and the game definately isn't worth the full asking price.

..So why does this game still get a positive review from me? Hell if I know. I'm still caught in the charm like anyone else who loves the series. Sure, it was mindless, tedious work. Sure, it wasn't really all that fun..but I'll be damned if I said I wanted to stop, because for some god-only-knows reason, I didn't. Pick the game up for 7-8, and you'll be golden. 

Game is honestly like a 3 out of 10 if you look at it from an objective point of view.

When you're actually playing it though, it's a solid 7. You should get it.

23529611.review:
[h1][b]¿QUÉ ES HYPERDIMENSION NEPTUNIA U: ACTION UNLEASHED[/b][/h1]

Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed es un spin-off de la saga creada por Compile Heart/Idea Company, quien toma las riendas Tamsoft (Senran Kagura Saga) en un beat 'em up que deja un tanto que desear hablando de varios aspectos como gameplay, historia o rejugabilidad.

[h1][u]LO BUENO[/u][/h1]

• Animaciones únicas que refrescan las vistas anteriormente.

• … y la verdad no se que mas poner.

[h1][u]LO MALO[/u][/h1]

• Repetitivo; pierde su gracia en un par de horas.

• Menos personalización que en los juegos anteriores de Neptunia.

•  Dialogo e historia aburridas para los estándares de la saga


[h1][u]Mi Opinión...[/u][/h1]

Tengo un placer culposo en los videojuegos, y dicho es la saga Hyperdimension Neptunia. No niego que son juegos casi mediocres a comparación de otros JRPG y que tampoco son materiales inspiradores para otras compañías o desarrolladores, pero tienen su encanto “estúpido” que logró cautivarme. Sin embargo cuando llega este titulo a mis manos… bueno, digamos que mi sensación es disonante.
Soy, también, un amante de los beat 'em up pero mas aun los que tienen profundidad jugable tales como DMC o MGR, incluso Bayonetta u otros ejemplos que no se me ocurren por el momento. Pero al contrario, este NeptuniaU es realmente simplista y la definición de “machaca botones”. Quizás lo mas insultante sea que este spin-off ofrece una mirada diferente del JRPG que podria haber sido mucho mejor si se tratase con mas cariño, pero da la impresión de ser otro proyecto de medio tiempo. Y sobre el fanservice…. Que buena época para estar vivo!!!

[B]NOTA:[/b][i] *C-*[/i] –  Un flojo, poco memorable y repetitivo a mal beat 'em up del mundo de una franquicia que aprecio. A pesar de que demuestra un poco del potencial que puede llegar Hyperdimension Neptunia a otros juegos.


[i]¿DEBERIAS PAGAR FULL-PRICE?[/i]
No, sin embargo a un buen descuento puede que llame tu atencion a pesar de los inconvenientes que puede llegar a presentar.

23458842.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed es un spin-off del género hack'n'slash que le da [b]un soplo de aire fresco[/b] a la franquícia.

Gráficamente [b]está correcto[/b]. Los personajes tienen el mismo modelo que en los Re;Birth, aunque [b]bastante refinados en cuanto a movimientos[/b]. En Re;Birth, los personajes pecaban de moverse a veces muy ortopédicamente, pero en este juego se [b]mueven con una suavidad y naturalidad impresionante[/b]. Ya puedes enlazar las habilidades que quieras y hacer los combos que te dé la gana que el personaje siempre se moverá con suma naturalidad.

El menú de pausa incluye un modo que quita la interfaz y nos deja manejar una cámara libremente que [b]es perfecto para hacer capturas[/b] (si eres de a los que le gusta hacer capturas mientras juega, gracias a esa opción te van a salir de muy guapas).

Los escenarios son la gran mayoría [b]calcos exactos[/b] de las mazmorras de Re;Birth 1 y 2. No es un punto malo, al contrario, se siente muy guay luchar en tiempo real en ellos.

Además, ya sea con programas externos (como GeDoSaTo) o modificando los Factores DSR de nuestro panel de control de Nvidia, [b]podemos reescalar el juego para que se vea espectacular[/b], sin un solo borde de sierra o efecto blurry.

La banda sonora [b]está bastante bien[/b]. Muy pegadiza y con temas de Re;Birth 1, 2 y 3.

El juego [b]se maneja muy bien[/b]. Los controles reaccionan de forma muy suave y es muy fácil de jugar, aunque [b]se echa en falta algo de profundidad en el tema de los combos[/b] (ya que son algo simplones).

Además de los combos, cada personaje podrá usar [b]hasta 3 habilidades especiales[/b] (las cuales gastan gastan "cargas SP", que pueden recuperarse infligiendo/recibiendo daño). También tendremos la clásica [b]"Unidad EXE"[/b], que en este juego es una barra que al llenarla (se llena infligiendo/recibiendo daño), podremos [b]activar la forma HDD[/b] del respectivo personaje (esta forma, al igual que en los Re;Birth, aumentará todas las estadísticas del personaje y también le otorgará nuevos movimientos), la cual [b]dura un tiempo limitado[/b].

Tendremos hasta [b]10 personajes jugables[/b]: 4 CPUs, 4 Candidatas y 2 Periodistas (estas 2 últimas son nuevas de este juego). [b]Se echan en falta personajes desbloqueables[/b] o algo, ya que obtenemos los 10 al empezar el juego.

Para cada misión tendremos que escoger a[b] 2 personajes, que irán emparejados[/b] (un gran detalle es que todos [b]tienen interacciones y conversaciones entre ellos[/b]).

Al igual que en los Re;Birth, los personajes [b]subirán de nivel[/b] al acabar con enemigos y podremos [b]modificarles su equipamiento[/b]. El tema del equipamiento [b]está bastante limitado[/b]: a cada chica podremos equiparle un arma, un traje, un accesorio y tres habilidades especiales. Para conseguir ese equipamiento, tendremos que acabar con un número de enemigos de una especie en concreto ([b]no hay que comprarlo[/b]). Por ejemplo, al igual para conseguir X espada para Neptune tienes que derrotar 999 Dogoos.

El famoso Costume Break (razón por la que muchos os compraréis el juego, guarrillos) [b]también afecta a la jugabilidad[/b]. Cuanto más nos peguen, más se nos irá rompiendo la ropa hasta llegar al "Costume Break" (a partir de aquí ya no se rompe más, sorry). Al ocurrir, nuestro personaje [b]podrá activar su forma HDD automáticamente[/b] (la barra de Unidad EXE se llena golpe) y [b]tendrá más golpes críticos[/b].

Ahora vayamos a la parte que tira por la borda todo lo dicho anteriormente: el juego es [b]sumamente repetitivo[/b] (y acaba haciéndose muy pesado).

Lo empiezas con mucho "hype" por lo agradable de sus controles y porque vas probando personajes nuevos, pero al rato te das cuenta que el juego no es más que [b]un aburrido aporrea botones[/b]. Las misiones son [b]casi todas iguales[/b] (acaba con todos los enemigos o X cantidad de enemigos). Los desarrolladores intentan darle algo de variedad con algunas misiones de objetivos ocultos que tienen algún pequeño puzzle, [b]pero no es suficiente[/b]. 

Se echan en falta jefes finales (solo hay uno y es al final), niveles de llegar a una meta, etc... No sé, [b]variedad[/b], no hacer exactamente lo mismo en cada misión.

Además el juego [b]apenas supone un desafío[/b] (es muy facilón y si luego le sumamos una característica que se desbloquea al pasarte la historia principal, ya ni te cuento), los diálogos de la historia [b]se alargan absurdamente[/b] y llegan a desesperar (esto no me molestaría si no fuese porque es un hack'n'slash y tanta charla acaba poniendo nervioso) y [b]es algo corto[/b] para ser un Neptunia (la historia al igual te la terminas en 20-25h, pero hay que entender que no es un RPG).

A partir de aquí hablo de todo el contenido [b]post-game[/b] del juego, así que si quieres guardártelo como una sorpresa, [b]no leas lo que viene ahora[/b]:

[spoiler]Al completar la historia, se desbloqueará la Neptral Tower y el Gamindustri Gauntlet.

El primero es una torre de 50 pisos que tendremos que completar con los 10 personajes jugables (bueh, es cansina pero viene bien para farmear Rangos Lily) y el segundo es un torneo en el que escojeremos personaje y dificultad y tendremos que luchar en un ring contra personajes controlados por la CPU (combates 1v1). Este segundo [b]podría haber sido[/b] perfectamente un [b]modo multijugador[/b], pero bueno...

También desbloquearemos los "Cheats", con los que podremos hacer que nuestros personajes nunca sufran daños, matar a cualquier enemigo de un golpe, etc... (cosa que hace el juego [b]aún más fácil[/b], aunque ya de forma descarada)
[/spoiler]

En definitiva, el juego es bueno en todo excepto en su [b]ejecución[/b] ([b]demasiado repetitivo y fácil[/b]) y en mi opinión, decepcionante. Aun así le doy el aprobado porque [b]mantiene todo el carisma de la franquícia intacto[/b] y [b]es un buen port[/b].

Lo recomiendo si no eres alguien muy exigente, eres muy fan de la franquícia o solo quieres pasar un rato con chicas monas matando cosas tranquilamente y sin muchos problemas.

23440101.review: My Dad Calls Me A Pedophiles and a Pervert 11/10 Would Nep Again

23389518.review:
[h1] A Review On Hyperdimension Neptunia U[/h1]
[b] Rating: 9/10[/b]
This was all around a great game. It's right down the alley for old fans of the series and new people who saw it pop up in their recommended list.

[b] Gameplay	[/b]
Unlike the previous turn-based combat of the rest of the franchise to this date, Neptunia U takes the hack n' slash route of RPGs. Combat in Neptunia U is extremely satisfying for a few hours, but then kind of loses its novelty after that period of time. Eventually you find a broken combo on a broken CPU, say Blanc, and spam her X+X+X+X+Y+Y combo which absolutely destroys and nothing really happens, not to mention the CPUs and Candidates are nowhere close to being equal in strength, and here's a breakdown of their power.

1. Neptune: She's the original MC of the series. Her X combo whilst in HDD does this insane AOE spin attack that destroys, whilst her non HDD form is simply forward directional attacks. Nothing special.
2. Noire: One of my favorite characters, she is surprisingly less powerful than I expected. Whilst she can go toe to toe against most enemies, her Y, which is her few AOE wave clear attacks takes a while to set up, making her damage output less that some other characters'.
3. Blanc: Some people hate on Blanc for having slow attacks, but on the contrary, her mobility combo in HDD of X+X+X+X+Y+Y makes her near untouchable and can deal 4000+ damage a hit at level 35. Blanc, at that point, is absolutely broken.
4. Vert: One of the most OP characters, her Y combos in the middle of her X combos allows her to dash from place to place, making Vert unhittable.
5. Nepgear: Her skill set is quite the same as Neptune's in HDD, but in her regular form, her X combo can extend a Y at the end which functions as a dash, much like Vert.
6. Uni, AKA Skillshot God: Why is Uni called this? Well, all her attacks are very directional. Her Ys are, most of her Xs are, and in HDD, every single attack points at the first direction the first attack goes, especially in her X combo, allowing you to move and kite every single enemy, point the gun at them, and spam. Her Y is also broken AF but takes an insane amount of time to charge up, rendering it useless when she's crowded.
7. Rom and Ram, AKA Spam Gods: I'm lumping them together due to their similar movesets. Most of their Xs in HDDs are directional, and the Ys are basically spam damage-all-enemies-in-a-huge-cone type attacks.
8. Dengekiko and Famitsu: Wow, are these 2 journalists underpowered. I mean, I swear nobody uses them unless they have to. Their basics are weak, they have no mobility or surround AOE except for Dengekiko's Ys in combo with Xs or out. 

And of course, every Neptunia game has some broken item. In Neptunia 1, it was probably the Stamina Band that gave you 5000 extra health, in Neptunia 2 it was the FREE Gehaburn for Nepgear that let you one-shot every monster for at least 30 levels. In this game, it's that Scrambler Drive that allows you to, get this, instantly HDD at the beginning of every game. Couple that with the HDD gained from Costume Break, It essentially allows for each character you bring in to use their BROKEN AF EXE Drive twice. Wow.

[b] Story	[/b]
For all of you long-time fans out there, you all know that Neptunia is a story-centered game. This game is chock full of the standard Neptunia humor. For all of you noobs out there, that includes the boob jokes, [i]RIP Blanc Forever ;([/i], classic 4th wall breaks, which Idea Factory did a great job with, and the general personality of your favorite characters. However, the story is stretched a bit thin. The "Quests" in the game are the same thing, with "Irregular Quests" being the same thing but with special rules! Wow, originality. Not to mention that the story will only progress with the completion of these Irregular Quests. I was not nearly as engaged by the story in U than by the turn-based combat games, but after all, it's probably harder to time random dialogue sequences in the middle of an X combo, right?
Even if the story is not as good as the previous ones, It is still good enough to keep me playing, and the humor makes it funny as well.

[b] The Mechanical Bit	[/b]
This section will include graphics, sound, all that stuff.
Graphics:
Much like the rest of the games, the graphics are eh, good enough. The textures have been ripped straight from the other games and so were the enemies. Just look at the Rival Mech and Herobo from Neptunia 1, etc. 
Sound:
Though Idea Factory takes a lot of songs from the first games, like $100 and Nepgear's theme, I don't care, because those songs are great. The opening song is also what I've come to expect from these games, and Idea Factory once again delivers. 
Optimization and Hardware for all of you PC Nerds:
I run an Nvidia GTX 970, and it works like a charm. 300+ FPS at the most lag-inducing times, and from what I've seen, it has worked on the equivalent of a mac. Good for Idea Factory, making their games playable.

In Summary: Whether you're a new person to the series, or a hardcore Neptunia fan who's in it for another game, like the rest coming out this summer (Victory II I'm looking at you), these Neps you're getting from this Nep is well worth the Neps spent on this Nep.

Nep.

A different genre than the usual Neptunia games, with action-based gameplay, similar to the Dynasty Warriors series. The cast is the usual CPU characters, their sisters and two new journalists.

23013650.review:
I've been a fan of the 'Warriors/Mosuo' series for almost 15 years now. It has become something of a trend in recent years for all manner of series to have their own 'Warriors' spin-off.
When it came to Neptunia's hack and slash spin-off, I anticipated something along the lines of the 'Dynasty Warriors: Gundam' series; lots of characters from the Neptunia francise, with the Lily Rank system following along the lines of DW:G3's operator system.
To put it simply, I expected to have more than ten characters; I was at least hoping a few Makers would be featured in this game. Perhaps it was naive of me to expect Compile Heart/Idea Factory to actually put some effort into their games, but I was trying to be optimistic about this game.
All that said, however, I was not massivly disappointed with this spin-off. The characters all use their Hyperdimension designs and personalities, all the CPUs are given some respect (even the Candidates, who seem to have become the series' chew toys as of late), there's around 10-15 hours of gameplay if you simply plough through it all, and the Lily Rank system was more fleshed out and entertaining than usual, with short voice clips available between all characters as their ranks go up.
Characters are hardly balanced, gameplay-wise. Vert is insanly mobile; Uni, Rom and Ram are highly mobile with long range attacks. This makes them more effective for most of the game, while Blanc and Noire are basically useless. Fortunatly, while Purple Heart is not as mobile as Vert, and Purple Sister use melee instead of ranged attacks, the Nep sisters are easily the most powerful characters(as they damn well should be.)
I do appreciate that the designers bothered to make character designs and movests for Denkiko and Famistu(both of whom were previously Chirper-only characters) however, I was left to wonder why IF and Compa, who do appear in this game, are not playable. Again, this links back into the overall lack of Human characters here, but why put them in the game in the first place if you won't allow me to play as them?
Overall, it's a decent hack and slash. Just don't expect too much from it, and try and purchase it while it's on sale.

22973891.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U is an unusually low quality game for the series. If you hadn't already guessed, this game is a Dynasty Warriors-esque game where you need to mow down waves of enemies to win. But the game lacks even the most basic features anyone has come to expect from the Hack and Slash genre. 

The main problem is that the game never tries to do anything more than that. DW and every variation at least has some variation on killing enemies - your objective is rarely just 'Kill 1000 dudes': they're far more often to the effect of capturing areas, defending teammates or killing key enemies to push the battle in your favor in sprawling maps where there's plenty to do. As it turns out being stuck in a claustrophobic space with no reason to do anything other than spam your light attack gets boring real fast.

And that's quite the issue. The game never requires you to do anything other than spam one button. Even in the most basic of this genre, considering whether to use a single or multi-target move or expend a special bar is always present. But here, using anything but the patented 'spam x' strategy is horrendously inefficient. You might question the use of efficient in a context like this, but it will be at the forefront of your mind when playing this game. There is an ungodly amount of grinding. If you want to complete this game, you will need to grind. Each. And. Every. Character. There is no catch up mechanic. The only way to level those character you don't want to play but have to is to find yourself a nice long mission with lots of enemies and switch your brain off for a few hours.

In addition, the game seems to have a hard time conveying itself to the player. There are numerous points which are scarcely explained or expanded upon. Quite often I had found myself in a mission killing hundreds of enemies only to grind to a scrreching halt as only one enemy appeared on the map. In order to complete the mission I had to defeat the last 50 enemies one by one. These were also bosses so they took at least a minute to kill. This turned a five minute mission in a twenty minute mission that was painful to play. Even after searching all over the (very small) map for additional enemies, there was nothing. I refuse to believe the devs were genuinely incompetent enough to consider this sort of thing a mechanic, so I can only assume this was a glitch.

For some reason there is also no autosave. Maybe in the hopes you'll accidently erase your progress and waste more time?

Too much of this game feels like cheap padding to push the playtime of the game upwards to justify its price tag. Unfortunately the core mechanics are far too barren to even consider it. Ultimately there is no reason to enjoy this game: the graphics are upscaled vita models, the soundtrack is tiny, the gameplay is incredibly boring with zero depth or interesting mechanics and the story is hardly interesting enough to justify the slog. If you're interested in a Hack and Slash, try Dynasty Warriors 8, Pirate Warriors 3 or Hyrule Warriors. All three are far more developed and interesting than this game.

I don't mind Japanese voices, but the community was eagerly waiting for something like this.

Thirdly, the graphics. It's not meant to be realist, and it's better that way. Mainly because a Neptunia game drawn like The Last of Us or Uncharted 4 would look strange, but also because it keep with the anime environment. 22858098.review:
Fans of Hyperdimension Neptunia will be expecting their favourite characters to duke it out against recognisable enemies. Those fans won't be disappointed. You can choose from the main CPU's and their candidates (poor candidate-less Vert) as they battle in a Dynasty Warriors-esque spin on the franchise.

Special skills are unleashed via a pop-up menu accessed on a button press (controller recommended here), with your SP displayed as little blue pills in your status bar. Each pill represents 1000 SP, and each skill consumes a multiple of 1000 so it's a resource you'll run out of quicky. Fret not, however, as the enemies will often drop Hero Drinks which replenish your HP and restore some vital SP.

You can choose up to two characters per battle. One character will fight and the other recovering HP in the background, which you can switch at will. All characters have a transformation or 'HDD' mode true to the original games, which vastly increases your stats and even changes your skills in some cases. Use of this mode requires you to fill an 'EXE' guage which fills faster if your character is out of combat.

Getting hit results in damage to whatever outfit you happen to be wearing. This means two separate sets of damage, both for your standard outfit and HDD modes. The exception to this are the two journalists, Dengekiko and Famitsu who use the same outfit for both modes as they don't have a 'true' HDD mode.

Destroying your outfit means taking more damage overall, but heavier hits and more chances to fill the EXE bar, which means more opportunity for unleashing HDD mode. In addition, the EXE bar also grants you a super move which can empty an entire room and demolish boss monsters in mere moments. This can be used in HDD mode as well for a truly devastating attack, though it drains the EXE bar and you will revert back to normal afterwards.

In addition to the action, there is plenty of voice work the fan favourite VA's from franchise. For me, just listening to their banter is as entertaining as the action itself as they constantly break the 4th wall and make subtle and not-so subtle references to other video game franchises.

It's hard not to recommend the game. It knows exactly who it's target audience is and gives them what they want. Newcomers to the series might feel a bit lost and won't understand some of the references made (some refer to prior Hyperdimension games) but can enjoy it for what it is. A quirky action game with a healthy dose of humour to keep you entertained.

22736376.review:
TL;DR: It sucks. Details below. Only buy it if you're a Neptunia fan that feels the need to play all the games. If you like this type of combat game, just wait for Senran Kagura since that's the much better original this game is trying to rip off.

This game does not deserve the high review rating it has. Don't buy this game. I'll start with the positive things about the game, because they run out quick.

1. Game runs at a solid 60 fps and looks decent
2. The combat is fun for a while. Animations are great, some characters play really smoothly.
3. The dialogue is still the usual we've come to enjoy
4. Appearance customization is nice

Now for the bad things, in order of importance:

1. Weaker story/dialogue than the other games. A lot of charm in the Neptunia games comes from the dialogue between characters. The way this game is set up, that happens a lot less frequently. It's just quest after quest after quest and then eventually you'll get something, and the cycle repeats. If the dialogue was good/frequent enough, it would make the game bearable. Unfortunately it isn't.

2. Holy hell is this game grindy. Every quest, no matter what kind of "twist" they try to put on it, is the same: kill a bunch of enemies. Some take forever to die, the bosses take forever to spawn, missions take a long time for no reason at all. Achievements are even worse. For example, Neptral Force requires you to play through 50 floors 5 times, since the requirement is to beat all 50 with all 10 characters (it's only 5 times because you can run through it in pairs).

3. The combat gets boring quick. It's fun at first, but you do so much of the same so often you'll eventually get sick of it. It's even worse if you want all the achievements, since that requires you to do 

4. Enemies have no variety. They are all exactly the same, you never change your strategy for any of them, they just look different. And the health bars are damn near invisible so you can only tell if you killed something by the death sound which gets annoying when repeated.

5. The game is not hard at all. This makes it feel even more like a chore because since it's so easy, you'd wish it goes by faster, but it doesn't.

6. The quest layout isn't optimal. Ideally, it would list quests by level or quest type. Instead, it separates each quest by map (the maps do not affect gameplay enough to warrant this), making finding level-appropriate quests incredibly annoying.

7. Equipping accessories is annoying. Since in this game you can only send out 2 people at a time, there's no need for items to be limited. That means equipping accessories on one person won't prevent someone else from equippping it. The problem with this is that there's basically no reason for anyone to have different loadouts, yet they do, so it takes like 5 minutes to change everyone to the same loadout.

8. While the game looks decent, it's just upscaled 720p. There's a mod to fix this, but we shouldn't have to install a mod for this sort of thing. Resolution won't go higher than 1080p either.

9. The music is not fitting in the least. Since they're just using tracks from the previous games, sometimes they'll stick an unfitting track on an unfitting map. This is a battle game yet you'll have non-battle music playing all the time, it's oddly distracting.

22651400.review:
[h1] We need less goddamit! LESS IS MORE! [/h1]

Finally, Neptunia spin-offs are starting to appear on steam. What that means is: 
1. More games for the fans and newcomers.
2. ...Let's face it you're all here for the animu fanservice, aren't ya?

[b][i] Story [/i][/b]

Right of the bat the game informs you that it's a spin-off and the story is non-canon.
Despite that the cast is still the same good ol' CPU goddesses and their sisters. They are accompanied by two journalists Dengekiko and Famitsu, and together they try to uncover a new Scoop. Yup, that's pretty much the entire plot.

The story's quite short, and unless you're playing the game once a week or so, you'll finish it in a jiffy.

[b][i] Gameplay [/i][/b]

As stated before, this is a spin-off. Instead of a JRPG, NepU is an Action Beat-'em-Up with RPG elements, it's quite fun. The controls are fluid. Characters have special skills, combos, transformations (just like before) , though the amount of combos could have been more varied.

The game also features the "Costume Break" system. It gives the characters a boost in stats... and it's for fanservice purposes too: get hit enough times and your controlled characters will get their costumes ripped to shreds with only a few scraps left to cover the goodies. Depending on whether you like the cutesy characters running around almost naked it's a hit or miss. Luckily the feature can be disabled midgame for those who don't like it.

[b][i] Graphics and Sounds[/i][/b]

The game retains what is great about the previous Neptunia games - the colorful atmosphere, funky battlemaps to fight in and good looking character and enemy models (though a lot are the same as in the previous games from the franchise).

The soundtrack is typical Neptunia - Funky, with some 8bit mixed here and there followed by JRPG battle rock themes. I didn't get bored of those. (Some themes reused, but not a lot.) A great plus is that there is a sound gallery for listening to the previous Nep game tunes, great for relistening pleasure.


[b][i] Problems?[/i][/b]

A game can't have zero downsides right? Of course. There were reports of crashing, blurry 1080p graphics,sound, controller and performance issues on launch, luckily most of the issues were either fixed, or are easy to fix thanks to the community findings.

Another little problem that sparked some controversy in community discussions was the Costume Break, and how it looks "wrong" on the younger members of the cast (the Goddess' siblings), I can't say which side is right, but it's something to think about, as some parts of the world have very harsh laws regarding this topic.

And finally probably the most talked problem - the difficulty. The game is well, too easy. Mobs can swarm you but they attack very rarily and deal insignificant damage, and even then you usually have a partner character that you can switch to. You can equip accessories that lower your stats yes, but that unnatural difficulty raising doesn't feel rewarding at all.
Of course there are DLCs with harder quests, but by the time you get to them, the main story is finished, and unless you want to play more against one-shot mobs, those quests aren't worth the time.

[b][i]Summary[/i][/b]

NepU - the first Neptunia spin-off on steam started it off strong - a solid different genre game with it's own fickles and trickles. While it has some problems with it's low difficulty, fans of the franchise will enjoy it. And for those who are checking out this franchise just now, go ahead. Though you might want to wait for a discount if you're unsure if it's a worthy buy, though for a casual fun game - I recommend it.

22580074.review:
You know why you're here so I won't waste time.

[h1]Some Facts[/h1]

A Neptunia-themed arena-based hack 'n slash game. A port of the Vita game. All characters have light/strong attacks, aerial combos, special attacks (a.k.a SP Skills), and a temporary transformation ability (HDD/CPU mode) which changes up some moves and increases the character's power and survivability. Characters may use a powerful super ability (EXE Drive) once transformed which will revert them to their regular state. You build SP and meter by landing attacks. You usually have to kill everything in an arena to win. You can take two characters into battle and swap between them as necessary. The game encourages you to swap by filling the transformation meter of the inactive character first, then for the active character.

The playable characters are the CPUs who have CPU Candidates, and the CPU Candidates themselves, plus Famitsu and Dengekiko. Characters gain EXP and level up, increasing their stats. Killing monsters nets you medals for each type of monster (Dogoo, Pixelvader, etc.) which you can trade in for permanent stat boosts, equippable stat items, or weapons. Also, as two characters complete battles, their friendship rank (Lily Rank) goes up, conferring bonuses to each character. You also get costumes, and a sound test mode.

Story's your standard Neptunia fare of "evil thing appears, go murder it". The writing is very similar to the main Neptunia games and the characters retain their personalities. Once you finish the main quests, you unlock a tournament mode, and then a 100-floor tower to work up.

The port has a 60 FPS lock. It will at times slow to below that for a few seconds, usually after many particle effects, or switching windows. The game runs natively at 720p, causing blurry assets, but can run at 1080p with better anti-aliasing using durante's GeDoSaTo program. The options menu is extensive for a port, and can be viewed on the [url=http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Hyperdimension_Neptunia_U:_Action_Unleashed]PCGamingWiki[/url]. This is on an i7-2600k with a GTX 660Ti.

[h1]Some Positives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Characters all control tightly thanks to the decent framerate.
[*]Tsunako's character art is stellar as always.
[*]Particle effects are good-looking and not overly taxing.
[*]Character models are good quality.
[*]Music is cheery when it needs to be, and omnious when it needs to be.
[*]Port is rock-steady and well done considering the source.
[*]Smashing hordes of monsters feels good in a musou-game kind of way.
[*]Each character's personality comes through in their unique moveset and combat quotes.
[*]Surprising amount of items to unlock for min/maxing purposes.
[/list]
[h1]Some Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*]Ranged/Spellcaster characters are extremely overpowered compared to the melee characters due to how hitstun works and how enemies tend to swarm you in melee range. Monsters will likely never touch a ranged character if played properly. It certainly feels bad when you avoid using your favourite character because she's objectively worse.
[*]The L button centers the camera. The X button is the light attack. L+X activates EXE Drive, nukes the screen, and knocks you into your regular mode. It's a pain.
[*]L must be held for a second to center the camera. Tapping won't do. This has no place in an action game.
[*]Two parts of the game are left untranslated, probably because they had no subtitles. The tournament commentary, and the Lily dialogue between characters.
[*]Tournament mode is a waste of time. The game is clearly not balanced so one-on-one combat ends pretty quickly.
[*]Speaking of on-on-one combat, sometimes the game ropes you into fighting lone minibosses/bosses. The game is clearly not designed for this.
[*]One ranged enemy type fire projectiles that will stunlock you into oblivion. There are no recovery i-frames to thwart this.
[/list]
[h1]Some Things To Read And Decide For Yourself If You Like[/h1]
[list]
[*]The localized English is very, very liberal with their translation. If you actually know Japanese you'll probably find yourself sliding a Glock between your teeth during extended cutscenes.
[*]You will do a lot of the same thing over and over.
[*]You might not want to let people watch you play this.
[*]Low skill ceiling. For melee characters, you figure out the optimal combo with the widest area of effect and least hitlag, then enter HDD for the rest of the quest. For ranged/casters, you enter HDD as soon as possible and fire while moving.
[*]Rom and Ram are basically the same character save minor changes in moveset and the behaviour of their projectiles in HDD. I know they're similar according to the lore but they could have played up Rom's affinity for ice magic and Ram's strength a bit more.

Either way, if you like the characters this is a way to finally see them in action. The combat is decent enough, and smashing monsters with Neps doesn't really get old if you have a good podcast on.

Hope this helped.

Reminder that Nepgear did nothing wrong.

22399908.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a spinoff musou-style beat 'em up to the Neptunia franchise, which came out originally on PS Vita in 2015, ported to PC and released on Steam almost a year later. In here, you take control of one of the familiar Neptunia characters and fight against huge hordes of monsters and occassionally bosses.

Graphic-wise, the game isn't much different from other Neptunia games already ported to Steam. The textures are a little blurry here and there, but it's nothing too bad. The animations for characters were also redone, and it's fun to watch their different combos.

In terms of music, it reuses a lot of tracks from the previous games, even including some of the favorites, like old battle themes and nation themes from each game. On top of that, it adds a few of its own amazing battle tracks, most of which playing during different HDD transformations - and all of them are awesome, whether you're talking about Perfect Purple, Black Brave, White Wings, Greedy Green or Eager Editor. They simply have that kick and "oomph" to them that makes them so satisfying to hear.

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty much what you would expect: you deploy on missions with a tag-team of two characters, defeating monsters, with a clear goal, which is usually "beat X monsters" or "defeat the boss", with some variations ever now and then. The difference is that you will take on tens or even hundreds of monsters at once, using characters' various abilities, from standard attacks, SP skills, to EXE Drives. You can also activate HDD to gain heightened stats and attack power, as well as a new, upgraded set of combos. You can also freely swap between team members at any given time, with the one in the back row slowly regenerating her health.
Another unique or... kind of unique feature is the Costume Break, where if your character takes enough damage, her clothes get ripped up for... fanservice's sake. It also affects your stats, lowering defense but increasing critical hit chance and giving you 50% extra EXE Drive gauge instantly. The presence of this mechanic is honestly not surprising, considering it is Neptunia, and it was also made by Tamsoft, known for their work on even more explicit but similar in nature [i]Senran Kagura[/i] series.

Story-wise, it's not nearly as good as the main series' RPG games. It follows our Goddesses as they are being interviewed by two new playable characters, Dengekiko and Famitsu (rather obviously based on Japanese gaming mags) as they take on a slew of new monster-slaying Quests, with a new emerging threat... which is so shallow that even the characters comment on it being so. While the extra scenes and the fourth-wall-breaking humor is like always top-notch, the story mode only takes about fifteen-twenty hours to complete, and that's not speedrunning it. Also the game is surprisingly easy, mostly due to how the stats scale and how the monsters aren't very mobile, even bosses just following the general "get close and launch an attack" schtick... [spoiler]well, at least outside of Gamindustri Gauntlet set to the highest difficulty level, and the Hard Mode DLC missions... and who can forget the final boss of the Neptral Tower being a stupidly-huge damage sponge, extending the fight to insane lengths? Thank God for cheats, even if they suck the challenge out of the game, at least they make it a little less tedious.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]Speaking of said Neptral Tower, being supposedly the final post-game content, it has rather idiosyncratic floor levels, frequently taking between ten seconds and five minutes in completion time, on top of level scaling that is just all over the place. You can have one floor have a reccommended level of 25, then the next having 5, and the one after that 44. On top of all that, to fully clear it, you will have to get all ten playable characters through this, and since you can only have two characters at a time, it'll take you a total of [b]five times[/b] to do.[/spoiler]

The last nitpicks from me is the fact that the roster of characters isn't balanced very well (shooter characters like Uni are hilariously easy to beat the game with if you know what you're doing), and sometimes even going HDD isn't the best option (Vert loses a lot of mobility and speed when she becomes Green Heart).
Also the series suddenly switched from using DirectInput controllers for Re;Birth games to using XInput ones. It's a little annoying on my side but nothing I can't work around easily.

Overall, I enjoyed the game until at least the general repetitiveness of the post-game content kicked in, but it is admittedly a short experience that definitely will not be appreciated by anyone who isn't already a Nep fan. If you really enjoy the Hyperdimension Neptunia games on Steam, go ahead and try it out, but otherwise it definitely isn't the best start with the series.

22348765.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]

Diverging from the Japanese style Role-Playing Game nature of the previous Re;Birth entries in the Hyperdimension Neptunia series currently available on Steam, Hyperdimention Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a Hack and Slash Action game. You will fight unyielding hordes of enemies simultaneously until the conditions of your current mission are satisfied. Set in a video game consoles inspired world, you will find many enjoyable references to other video games scattered throughout as you play.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game revolves around controlling one character at time on missions that take place in an arena like field. In most cases an optional second character can be waiting in the wings to take over for the current character if need be. Each mission has a success condition that must be met before the event is allowed to end. Typically, a mission involves killing unending throngs of monsters and often includes a few bosses sprinkled in for good measure. Since you are just one character, you have a number of abilities to help you achieve success. There is the normal attack, which is very effective in its own right, the heavy attack that is generally much more effective than the normal attack but has a drawback. Heavy attack helps to damage your costume each time you use it. Using these two types of attacks together allows you to make powerful combos. There are also special abilities that each character possesses that can really help turn the tide of battle in their favour. Once you have either been damaged enough or have done enough damage, a super powered option (HDD) becomes available. The HDD powered option is something like a new character entering the field.  It shares most of the same abilities as the character that summoned it but all of which are far more powerful than the normal version of them.

A battle damaged costume on a character reduces their defense but increases the rate in which their super power charges up. It’s a trade off but since the super power versions is significantly more powerful, it is generally worth it to let the costume become ruined through the over use of powerful attacks. If you prefer to make the game more challenging there is an unlockable outfit that can’t be damaged thus reducing the rate in which the super power charges. There is also the ability to start the round with the costume already damaged thus making your life more difficult early on as you wait for the super power to charge.

The majority of the game is spent on missions either doing them for the first time or repeating them to farm medals from the monsters found in that particular mission. Medals are used to unlock new weapons, power ups, and equipment in order to aid you to complete the more difficult missions. You will find yourself grinding away for them to some degree. Some monsters are common enough that you will hit the 999 cap without needing to farm them, others show up less often so you may have to actively hunt them down in old missions. Luckily missions can be completed rather quickly so it isn’t that painful to grind a mission repeatedly. This is especially true if you are supremely overpowered for that particular mission.

The charming mystery story of Hyperdimension Neptunia U revolves around two Gameindustri Journalists trying to outdo each other by getting the better scoop. They follow the CPUs (Console Patron Units) and CPU Candidates around out in the field trying to get material and images for their respective magazine articles and news reports. If you are a fan of visual novels or other games that put more emphasis on story and less on actual gameplay, Hyperdimension Neptunia U should be right up your alley. The game often finds itself broken off into long conversions taking place among a selection of the ten characters in-between missions. For the most part, the missions themselves really have no impact on the story and are just used as a device to transition between dialogues. There is nothing really wrong with this though as the fully voiced dialogues between the characters are almost always very humourous and fun to listen to. The way the characters interact with each other and have their own playful rivalries and friendships going on makes the game feel alive. There is no real method to impact on the conversations though so if you were to replay the game, you would hear the same dialogues each time. There are no prompts to select a topic or idea for them to discuss. You are really playing more of a passive role during these times.

Overall Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is a game that should satisfy Hyperdimension Neptunia fans as they get to interact with their favourite CPUs again and hear more of their story. Albeit, it is a story set in an alternate dimension and not considered cannon to the rest of the Hyperdimension Neptuna story. For people who like Visual Novels or Arena style Action battle games, Hyperdimension Neptunia U is a great place to get into the Hyperdimension Neptunia universe. There is a lot of story to enjoy without a lot of gameplay/questing getting in the way of it although there is no real way to drive the story yourself. If you are classic JRPG fan you may not like Hyperdimension Neptunia U as much as you would the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth series, which is an excellent series in its own right and you owe it to yourself to check it out. 

[list][h1]Pros:[/h1]
[*]The Hyperdimention Neptunia characters are back in an all new game
[*]While not as long as the Re;Birth series, U is a very lengthy game
[*]The characters feel alive, as if you are actually listening into potential real life conversations among friends
[*]Great Visual effects and accompanying Audio. The characters are all well detailed including some interesting “fan service” thrown in there as well if you are into that sort of thing
[*]Fully voice acted
[*]The controls work great for this game. Very fluid and easy to control. Making a combo doesn’t involve memorizing tons of nerve racking key presses in advance
[*]The idea that costumes can be damaged by the enemies attacks and through wear and tear makes for a more realistic element in the game 
[*]Unlockable content that helps make the game more enjoyable and stretches out gameplay
[*]Paid DLC are reasonably priced for what they give

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[*]Missions are very repetitive and not overly challenging once you get the hang of them. They feel like they were just thrown in as an afterthought to help break up the story a bit
[*]There is no story during a mission and the characters frequently repeat the same phrases to each other
[*]Combat is repetitive
[*]Since you have little impact to the story yourself, there is no real draw to replay it right away. Since it is a long game, I am perfectly fine with that, but it could be a negative to others who enjoy seeing multiple stories unfold in one game
[*]Achievements are a real grind fest[/list]

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Despite the fact combat and missions are repetitive, the mysterious and charming story behind Hyperdimention Neptunia U: Action Unleashed is enough to keep you wanting more. If you are a fan of the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, go for it, you likely won’t regret it. If you are new to the series and a JRPG fan, I’d say start with the Re;Birth series and then get U to enjoy more story related to your new found friends. If you are a fan of Bullet Hell style games where you are massively outnumbered and are fighting to survive, you likely would love U if you equip the forced Level 1 only accessory. Go ahead, give it a go!

22344103.review:
[quote]Originally exclusive to the PlayStation Vita, this action role-playing spin-off from the popular Hyperdimension Neptunia series brings in a fresh new take for the franchise enthusiasts and soon-to-be fans![/quote] 

[h1][u][b]Game Overview[/b][/u][/h1]

[b]Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed[/b] is set in the world of "Gamindustri" which is divided into four regions namely Planeptune, Lastation, Lowee, and Leanbox (in which three of them are intended puns for the popular modern consoles). Each of these regions have their own deities (to which they refer as CPUs) that oversee them, along with their candidates.

These CPUs and CPU Candidates, along with two Gamindustri Journalists, are the playable characters that you can choose to play as in each quest you engage (though there are some quests that restricts which characters you can use).

While this take differs heavily from the early ones in the series in terms of game play (as it focuses more on a straight-up action/hack n' slash theme), it carries on the charming, comedic, and quirky story of our heroines.


[h1][u][b]The Pros[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Excellent Art Design[/b] - This factor has always been present in games published/developed by Idea Factory, and that standard is still upheld in producing this one which is impressive to say at the very least. Also, the game has plenty of [i]"fan-service"[/i] that is dedicated for their fans with the addition of the [i]"Costume Break"[/i] feature.

    [*][b]Fluid Controls[/b] - The game plays absolutely smooth especially when you're using a gamepad. There's also a mapping tool to change the button assignment that fits to your play style.

    [*][b]Great Audio[/b] - From the great game soundtracks up to the impressive voice overs (which is both available in English and Japanese versions), the audio that is featured fits the theme of the game perfectly. You can even chill out and listen to the tracks that is available on the world menu.

    [*][b]Plenty of Contents to Unlock[/b] - There are tons of equipment, quests, and even a new game mode that you can unlock as you progress through, which contributes to the longevity of the game.

[/list] 


[h1][u][b]The Cons[/b][/u][/h1]

[list]

    [*][b]Short and Repetitive[/b] - Unlike the RPG versions of Hyperdimension Neptunia which showcases an average of at least a hundred hours of gameplay for the scope of the whole game, this hack n' slash spin-off could yield a total gameplay time of less than 70 hours to complete and is mostly a one-mode game which is repeated in a succession of quests.  

    [*][b]Inadequate Difficulty Levels[/b] - Honestly, if you look and consider that this game is pointed at casual gamers, the difficulty of the game is perfectly balanced. However, considering the gaming community as a whole, the difficulty level is relatively easy to the extent that I rarely fail an attempt on a quest, even when using characters that are below recommended level.

[/list] 


[h1][u][b]The Verdict[/b][/u][/h1]

To make it short, [b]Get it![/b] 

For those who are new to the franchise and is interested in trying the game but is concerned if they should get the other games first, do not worry as this game isn't heavy in terms of story and it is worth the buy. 

And for the long time fans of the series, getting this is a must.
